did.abstract: Mr. Mieczyslaw [Michael] Kierklo was born in Poland. He attended school and work there until the outbreak of WWII. In 1940 he was arrested by Russians and sent to Workuta, a labor camp. In 1942, after he was freed, he joined the newly established Polish Army in the USSR and left Russia with General Andres, and fought with them until the end of the war. In 1954 he immigrated to the US and established his life in Connecticut. He became very involved with various Polish and Polish American organizations. Soon his writing talent was used for various occasions. He wrote to publication called "Weteran" about his war experience and wrote about Polonia activities and events to the Polish daily Nowy Dziennik. For numerous occasions he wrote short poems to celebrate the live and activities of an organization or individual.

bioghist.head: Historical/Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Mieczyslaw Kierklo (May 18, 1919 - March 23, 2004). Mr. Kierklo was born in Poland in 1919, and worked in the aircraft industry in Rzeszow before the WWII. During the war he participated in the underground resistance movement and was arrested in 1940. Later, he was sent to labor camp in Workuta. After the Sikorski-Stalin pact to create the Polish Army in the USSR, he was released from Workuta and left Russia with General Anders army in 1942. During the war he fought with the First Polish Armoured Division under General Maczek.

Mr. Kierklo immigrated to the US in 1954 and lived in Newington, CT. He was active in Polish veteran's organizations, and the Polish American Congress. He was also active parishioner of the Holy Cross church and the Polonia Paderewski choir in New Britain, CT. He financially supported many domestic and international human rights organizations. Mr. Kierklo was very involved in the celebration of Poland's Millennium of Christianity in 1966. He was a writer and a poet, and he published several books of his poetry. Together with Mr. Jan Wojcik, they published "Polonia in Connecticut". He was regularly published in many Polish and Polish American magazines and newspapers. Mr. Kierklo wrote numerous short poems and limericks for various occasions, including anniversaries, birthdays, name days and other family celebrations.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents of the Collection
scopecontent.p: The collection consists of Mr. Kierklo memoirs published in the Polish language magazine, Weteran, and numerous articles from local Polish and Polish American newspapers. In addition, books written or co-written by Mr. Kierklo and anniversary pamphlet publications, are included. Correspondence and bulletins of local organizations and information about various political and cultural Polish American events are in the collection also.
